nexttext:
where $\omega_i$ is the natural frequency of the node, 
which is normally distributed with average $<\omega> = 1$ 
and standard deviation $\sigma_{\omega} = 0.02$. 

An isolated node with R\"{o}ssler dynamics 
can display periodic, quasi-periodic or chaotic dynamics
and we choose $a = 0.15$, $p = 0.2$ and $c = 10$ 
to set the oscillators into a chaotic regime 
	\cite{Boccaletti2002}. 

For all adjacent nodes $j = 1,\hdots,N_i$ of node $i$
the parameter $\alpha_{ij}$ corresponds to the strength
of the bidirectional coupling.

The dynamics of each pair of nodes can display 
NS (no synchronization), PS, GS, LS or CS
and can be characterized using the nearest neighbor method 
in the return maps of the two oscillators (see Fig.~\ref{fig:1}a, lower panels)
	\cite{Moskalenko2012}.

Coexistence of synchronization patterns occurs in 
prototypical SF, SW and RN networks.

Figure~\ref{fig:1}bcd shows
the distribution of the coupling strengths ($\alpha_{ij}$) 
and the distribution of synchronization patterns 
for each prototypical network. 

Hence, a question arises:
\textit{What are the conditions that are suitable 
for coexistent synchronization patterns in a network?}





\begin{figure}[ht]
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=\columnwidth, trim=0cm 0cm 0cm 0cm, keepaspectratio,clip=True]
{Figure_02.pdf}
\end{center}
\caption{(color online).  
{\bf Dependence of the coexistence of synchronization patterns on the Lyapunov Exponents.} 
(a) Simple weighted network formed by two pairs of peripheral nodes connected to a central node.
The couplings between peripheral node pairs are $\alpha_{12}=0.05$ and $\alpha_{34}=0.03$. 
(b) For each node dynamics the curves show the mean value (computed over 100 runs with random initial conditions) 
of the maximum Lyapunov exponent ($\lambda 1$) 
as a function of the strength of coupling $\alpha_c$ of all nodes with the central node. 

The lowest thin curve corresponds to the lowest values of $\lambda 1$ for node $\omega_1$
computed independently for each value of $\alpha_c$.
This curve crosses the zero line at  $\alpha_c = 0.06$, as indicated by an arrow and a vertical dotted line. 

The uppermost thin curve corresponds to the largest values of $\lambda 1$ for node $\omega_2$.
This curve crosses the zero line at  $\alpha_c= 0.23$, as indicated by an arrow and a vertical dotted line. 

(c) Histogram of the occurrences of the synchronized patterns for each node pair in the network.
Notice that in the interval $\alpha_c \in [0.06,0.23]$ 
several synchronization patterns may coexist for the same coupling $\alpha_c$,
depending only on the randomly chosen initial conditions.

Notice that the heterogenous pattern PS/LS is the most frequently observed.
Pattern PS/GS was rare and pattern GS/LS was never observed.
}
\label{fig:2}
\end{figure}





Let us consider a simple weighted network 
formed by two pairs of nodes 
bidirectionally coupled
to a central node with strength $\alpha_c$ (see Fig.~\ref{fig:2}a). 

The dynamics of all nodes is described by Eqs.~(\ref{eq:Eq_Rossler}),
with different frequencies, $\omega_i$ for each node, 
namely: 
$\omega_1=0.930$, 
$\omega_2=0.967$, 
$\omega_3=0.990$, 
$\omega_4=0.950$, 
$\omega_5=0.970$. 

The presence of synchronized chaos in this dynamical system is assessed by measuring 
whether the largest conditional Lyapunov exponents $\lambda 1_{w_i}$ are positive or negative
	\cite{Pecora1990, Rosenstein1993pp117}.

For each node dynamics we measure $\lambda 1_{w_i}$ 
as a function of the coupling strength $\alpha_c$ of all peripheral nodes
with the central node.

In order to observe coexistent synchronization patterns,
each peripheral nodes pair $(1,\!2)$ and $(3,\!4)$
must have different types of synchronization.

In the absence of central coupling
(i.e., with  $\alpha_c = 0$)
the couplings $\alpha_{12}$ and $\alpha_{34}$ were tuned 
irrespective of the initial conditions
such that the dynamics of the isolated pair $(1,\!2)$
is phase synchronization PS with $\alpha_{12}=0.05$ 
and the dynamics of pair $(3,\!4)$
is no synchronization NS with $\alpha_{34}=0.03$.

The frequencies $\omega_1,\hdots,\omega_5$ 
were kept constant and 100 experiments were performed 
with random initial conditions.

Figure~\ref{fig:2}b shows that the largest Lyapunov exponent
of all peripheral nodes tend to decrease as a function of $\alpha_c$.

The Lyapunov exponent $\lambda {1_{\omega 1}}$ is the first to cross
the zero line at $\alpha_c = 0.06$
and $\lambda {1_{\omega 2}}$ is the last to cross
the zero line at $\alpha_c = 0.23$.

Then, in the interval $0<\alpha_c \leq0.06$
the $\lambda 1$ of all nodes are positive.

This corresponds to a non-coexistent domain 
where the synchronization (if any) 
of both pairs $(1,\!2)$ and $(3,\!4)$
follows the phase synchronization pattern PS,
thus noted as PS/PS.


The other non-coexistent domain
is observed for $\alpha_c > 0.23$ with both peripheral node pairs 
following the lag synchronization pattern 
(LS/LS domain).





Figure~\ref{fig:2}c shows that different synchronization patterns 
coexist within this network as a function 
of the strength of the coupling in the interval $0.06<\alpha_c \leq0.23$.

At the beginning of the coexistent domain
the statistics shows that 
PS/GS and PS/LS modes appeared besides the PS/PS mode.

The most remarkable coexistent domain occurred
for $\alpha_c = 0.12$, with the chance to observe
five different synchronization patterns in the network,
i.e.,
PS/LS (60\%),
PS/PS (36\%),
LS/LS (2\%),
PS/GS (1\%) and
GS/GS (1\%).

Notice that GS/LS was never observed in our simulations
and for $\alpha_c > 0.16$ the most frequently observed pattern
was LS/LS.





Let us consider now the same network illustrated by Fig.~\ref{fig:2} with
the coupling between nodes $\omega_1$ and $\omega_2$ being the same
but between nodes $\omega_3$ and $\omega_4$
being fixed to $\alpha_{34}=0.20$,
such that their dynamics is lag synchronization LS. 

Figure~\ref{fig:3}a
shows the average curves of the largest Lyapunov exponent $\lambda 1_{w_i}$
as a function of the coupling strength $\alpha_c$
measured in 100 experiments 
in the interval $\alpha_c=0,\hdots,0.20$ 
by increments of 0.01.

The dynamics of each pair of nodes tends to display
the same pattern of synchronization irrespective of
the initial conditions.

For example, with $\alpha_c=0.04$
the dynamics of node pair $(1,\!2)$ is characterized by PS
in more than 80\% of the simulations, whereas
the same pair is characterized by LS
when $\alpha_c=0.18$ (Fig.~\ref{fig:3}a).

Conversely,
with both those values of $\alpha_c$
the dynamics of node pair $(3,\!4)$ is always characterized by LS
(Fig.~\ref{fig:3}a).

We define {\it consistency} as the capacity of a network 
to display the same coexistence pattern regardless of the initial conditions.

This consistency varies greatly
depending on parameters 
governing the intrinsic dynamics (e.g. oscillatory frequency),
the topological characteristics of the network (e.g., clustering), 
the strength of interactions (e.g. coupling strength) 
or a mixing of all these parameters. 



\begin{figure}[t!]
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=\columnwidth, trim=0cm 0cm 0cm 0cm, keepaspectratio,clip=False]
{Figure_03.pdf}



\end{center}
\caption{(color online). 
{\bf Consistency of the coexistence of synchronizations.} 
(a) Same network of Fig.~\ref{fig:2}a with 
coupling $\alpha_{34}=0.20$ for node pair $(3,\!4)$.
For each node dynamics the curves show the mean value
of the maximum Lyapunov exponent ($\lambda 1$) 
as a function of coupling strength $\alpha_c$
(see Fig.~\ref{fig:2}b).
The histogram shows the relative frequency of the synchronization patterns 
for selected values of  $\alpha_c$ 
($\alpha_c=0.04$, $\alpha_c=0.18$ indicated by the arrows).
GS: general synchronization; CS: complete synchronization;
LS: lag synchronization; PS: phase synchronization; NS: no synchronization (not shown in the histograms).

(b) Homogeneous hub network with all couplings weighted by $\alpha_c$.
The maximum Lyapunov exponent curves for each node dynamics are similar 
and the interval of $\alpha_c$ for coexistence of synchronization patterns is small.
The histogram shows the distribution of the synchronization patterns for $\alpha_c=0.18$.

(c) All-to-all network in which all couplings are weighted by $\alpha_c$. 
The interval for coexistence of synchronization patterns is also small
and occurs for smaller values of $\alpha_c$.
The histogram shows the distribution of the synchronization patterns for $\alpha_c=0.04$.
}
\label{fig:3}
\end{figure}





In the absence of any coupling between the peripheral pairs
the previous network becomes homogeneous
and only the imposed distribution of natural frequencies of the oscillators 
allows for coexistence of synchronization patterns 
as it breaks the symmetry of the network (see Fig.~\ref{fig:3}b).

The Lyapunov exponents $\lambda 1$ of all peripheral pairs
are generally positive and 
the interval of $\alpha_c$ values 
that allow the coexistence of synchronization patterns is very narrow,
for $\alpha_c > 0.17$.

An all-to-all network in which all peripheral couplings 
are weighted by the control parameter $\alpha_c$
is another example of homogeneous network
(see Fig.~\ref{fig:3}c).

These examples show that
consistency of synchronization dynamics emerging
from a system of coupled dynamical units becomes lower
with an increase of symmetry in network structure and dynamics.

In the particular case of a completely symmetrical system, 
(i.e., same frequencies of oscillation for nodes dynamics in a symmetric network) 
the transitions to synchrony
	\cite{Moskalenko2012,Leyva2012}
are sudden and without coexistent synchronization patterns.






Functional networks are usually constructed by means of establishing 
relationships between the dynamical evolutions of its (coupled) elements.

Thus, synchronization is an excellent probe for assessing 
a (non) trivial communication between two dynamical systems. 

The functional relationships can only be quantified by their statistics
and on the basis of our results we suggest
that the underlying network topology determines 
the consistency of the coexistence of heterogeneous synchronization patterns. 

This statement is illustrated by 
constructing a ``network-of-modules'',
where each module is exemplified by the networks presented 
in Fig.~\ref{fig:3}.

Figure~\ref{fig:4}a shows a network formed 
by three modules labeled A, B and C
interconnected through their hub node.

Figure~\ref{fig:4}b shows the synchronization patterns
for the node pairs within each module.


\begin{figure}[t!]
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=\columnwidth, trim=0cm 0cm 0cm 0cm, keepaspectratio,clip=True]
{Figure_04.pdf}
\end{center}
\caption{(color online).  
{\bf Construction of functional networks} 
(a) A structural network of modules is constructed
by linking a module A, corresponding to a peripherally coupled network (Fig.~\ref{fig:3}a),
with a module C, corresponding to an all-to-all network (Fig.~\ref{fig:3}c),
by means of node pair $(4,\!5)$ with coupling $\alpha_{4,5}=0.03$
and by linking the module C
with a module B, corresponding to an homogeneous hub network (Fig.~\ref{fig:3}b),
by means of node pair $(9,\!10)$ with coupling $\alpha_{9,10}=0.04$.
All other couplings are set equal to $\alpha_c = 0.04$.

(b) 
Histogram of the relative frequency of the synchronization patterns 
for all intramodule and for the two intermodule node pairs.

Notice that the consistency of synchronization patterns in 
modules B and C
is different from the consistency observed in isolated networks
with the same topology corresponding to modules B and C (see Fig.~\ref{fig:3}bc).

GS: general synchronization; CS: complete synchronization;
LS: lag synchronization; PS: phase synchronization; NS: no synchronization (not shown in the histograms).

(c) Functional networks can de determined on the basis of various threshold levels
of consistency (between 20\% and 60\%)
for each type of synchronization pattern.
}
\label{fig:4}
\end{figure}


The synchronization patterns 
of module A, B and C
can be compared to the synchronization patterns in
Figures~\ref{fig:3}a, \ref{fig:3}b, and \ref{fig:3}c,
respectively.

This comparison shows that the dynamics of synchronization is different 
if the three modules are embedded in a larger network
or if they are isolated.

For example, notice that node pairs of the homogeneous module B of Fig.~\ref{fig:4}b
show a CS pattern more often than LS, 
but CS was never observed in the isolated B module (Fig.~\ref{fig:3}b).

Therefore, the dynamics of coexistence in the large network is not just 
a simple juxtaposition of the dynamics of its composite modules.

Thresholds in the relative frequency of occurrence of each pairwise synchronization pattern 
can be used to detect the connections that occur more often
and set levels of consistency for each type of synchronization pattern
(Fig.~\ref{fig:4}c).

Hence, the {\it consistency} of each type of synchronization pattern
can be used to define functional networks.

This example shows that modules B and C are functionally connected in phase synchrony
with a consistency above 40\%,
but modules A and C were never consistently synchronized.








In conclusion, the results of the present study
suggest that it is rationale to assume that experimentally-based functional networks 
recovered from taking into account only one type of synchronization pattern
are likely to be biased.

Consistent dynamics eventually depends on the heterogeneity characteristics 
of the structural networks such that selected network topologies 
may have been retrieved much more often than others, 
as reported elsewhere
	\cite{Eguiluz2005,Bullmore2009}.

JGO also acknowledges support from the 
the Generalitat de Catalunya (project 2014SGR0947), the ICREA Academia programme, and from the

prevtext:
\title{Consistency of heterogeneous synchronization patterns in complex weighted networks}

                             
                             
                             
\author{D. Malagarriga}
\thanks{Electronic address: \texttt{daniel.malagarriga@upc.edu}; Corresponding author}
\affiliation{Departament de F\'isica, Universitat Polit\`ecnica de Catalunya. \\ Edifici Gaia, Rambla Sant Nebridi 22, 08222 Terrassa, Spain.}
\affiliation{Neuroheuristic Research Group, Faculty of Business and Economics, University of Lausanne. \\ CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland.}
\author{A.E.P. Villa}
\affiliation{Neuroheuristic Research Group, Faculty of Business and Economics, University of Lausanne. \\ CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland.}
\author{J. Garcia-Ojalvo}
\affiliation{Department of Experimental and Health Sciences, Universitat Pompeu Fabra. \\ Barcelona Biomedical Research Park (PRBB), Dr. Aiguader 88, 08003 Barcelona, Spain.}
\author{A.J. Pons}
\affiliation{Departament de F\'isica, Universitat Polit\`ecnica de Catalunya. \\ Edifici Gaia, Rambla Sant Nebridi 22, 08222 Terrassa, Spain.}
\email{daniel.malagarriga@upc.edu}

\date{\today}
\begin{abstract}  
We show that groups of interacting oscillators may synchronize in different ways within a single network. This diversity of synchronization patterns is promoted by increasing the heterogenous distribution of coupling weights  and/or asymmetries in small networks. We also analyze {\it consistency}, defined as the persistence of coexistent synchronization patterns regardless of the initial conditions. Our results show that complex weighted networks display richer consistency, suggesting why certain functional network topologies are often reconstructed when experimental data are analyzed.

\end{abstract}

\pacs{87.19.lm,82.39.Rt,89.75.Hc,64.60.aq}
\maketitle



Rhythmicity in nature is a widely studied phenomenon 
which emerges in the form of recurrent cyclic states, 
which may or may not have a well defined periodicity
	\cite{Goldbeter2007}, 
resulting in a broad range of dynamics,
from simple harmonic oscillations to 
nonlinear deterministic chaos 
	\cite{landa2012regular, westra2013oscillators}. 

The interaction of a pair of rhythmic elements embedded in large networks
may entail the adjustment of their oscillatory dynamics 
towards a state of (dynamical) {\it agreement} or {\it synchronization}
	\cite{pikovsky2003synchronization, strogatz2003sync, strogatz2001, Glass2001}
categorized in four patterns
	\cite{Xiao-Wen2007}:

Complete synchronization (CS) is observed 
when both oscillations are identical or almost identical
	\cite{Boccaletti2002}. 

Phase synchronization (PS) appears
if the functional relationship between the dynamics of two oscillators 
preserves a bounded phase difference
	\cite{rosenblum1996}. 

Lag synchronization (LS) appears if the amplitude correlation is high 
and at the same time there is a time shift in the dynamics of the oscillators
	\cite{Rosenblum1997}.

Generalized synchronization (GS) is observed
if a complex functional relationship is established between the oscillations
	\cite{Abarbanel1996}. 




A fundamental question in network science is the relationship 
between network dynamics and network structure.

In the past, studies of the synchronization patterns in networks of oscillators 
were mainly aimed at describing the conditions 
associated with the emergence of specific synchronization patterns
in all the nodes
	\cite{Chavez2005}. 

In the particular case of complex networks of coupled nonlinear oscillators,
recent studies have provided evidence that 
it is possible to identify an appropriate interaction regime 
that allows to collect measured data
to infer the underlying network structure
based on time-series statistical similarity analysis
	\cite{Tirabassi2015}
or connectivity stability analysis
	\cite{Lin2015}.

In real-life systems,
such as
ecological networks
	\cite{blasius_complex_1999},
brain oscillations
	\cite{Robinson1998,Hill1997165,Cabessa2014}


or climate interactions
	\cite{Deza2015}, 
various types of complex synchronized dynamics have been observed.


In an evolving network
only certain oscillators may synchronize
	\cite{Schmidt2014}
and different types of synchronizations may appear at the same time~\cite{Burylko2014}. 

Such a diversity in dynamical relationships between the nodes
endows a network with stability, 
flexibility and robustness against perturbations
	\cite{zanette2004propagation}. 





Here, we study the dynamics of 
networks of coupled R\"{o}ssler oscillators 
arranged in complex weighted topologies 
--~random (RN)
	\cite{ErdosRenyi1959},
small-world (SW)
	\cite{watts1998cds} and 
scale-free (SF)
	\cite{Barabasi15101999}.

We show that several types of synchronization patterns may coexist
depending on the topology and on the distribution of coupling strengths within the network.

The novel finding of our study is the existence of regions 
in the parameter space where coexistence of synchronization patterns is stable. 

We relate the capacity of a network 
to display the same coexistence pattern regardless of the initial conditions 
with its {\it consistency}.

We suggest that the retrieval of a network structure
from its dynamics is very reliable 
when based on the consistency of coexistence patterns. 






\begin{figure*}[t!]
\includegraphics[width=\textwidth, keepaspectratio,clip=False]{Figure_01.pdf}
\caption{
(color online). 
{\bf Heterogeneous synchronization patterns in complex weighted networks.} 
(a) Examples of synchronization patterns
(no synchronization NS, phase synchronization PS, generalized synchronization GS, lag synchronization LS and complete synchronization CS)
displayed by coupled R\"{o}ssler oscillators using
the nearest neighbor plot for each dynamical state
	\cite{Moskalenko2012}. 
$\tau$ is the delay time for maximal cross-correlation in LS and PS.

Examples of (b) a scale-free (SF) network, 
(c) small-world (SW) network with low rewiring probability,
and (d) random (RN) network
of coupled R\"{o}ssler oscillators
displaying several interacting synchronization patterns. 

For each type of network the right panels show 
the distribution of the coupling strengths $\alpha_{ij}$ between pairs of nodes (upper panel)
and the distribution (polar histogram, lower panel) of the synchronization patterns. 
}
\label{fig:1}
\end{figure*}





Firstly, we set the dynamics of each node $i$ to follow the R\"{o}ssler equations:
